misconceptions.name: Program implements a different problem than the specification
misconceptions.description: The submission computes average acceleration from three inputs instead of reading five integers and summing the even ones, so it does not address the assigned task at all.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that solving the average-acceleration problem (with inputs v0, v1, and t) is the required task here.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must prompt for and read exactly 5 integers from the user and then compute and print the sum of only the even numbers among them.
symptoms: Prompt text asks for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of 5 integers
Only three values are read from input instead of five
Output describes 'average acceleration' instead of a sum of even numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: The student likely reused code from a different exercise (average acceleration) without adapting it to the current problem statement.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem description and rewrite main so that it reads 5 integers and computes the sum of the even ones instead of computing acceleration.
related_concepts: Mapping problem requirements to code structure
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: All variable names, prompt text, and formulas correspond to a standard average-acceleration exercise and do not match any part of the given specification.

evidence.note: Implements an average-acceleration calculation with three inputs and corresponding prompt/output, not reading 5 integers or summing even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Using double instead of int for integer-only input
misconceptions.description: The program uses double variables and nextDouble() for all user inputs even though the task requires reading integers.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student seems to believe that using double for numeric input is acceptable even when the problem specifies integers.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: When a problem specifically asks for integers, int variables and nextInt() should be used so that the types match the specification and intent.
symptoms: All three inputs are stored in double variables
Scanner is used with nextDouble() rather than nextInt()
misconceptions.root_cause: Overgeneralizing the use of double for numeric problems or reusing code from a previous floating-point example.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Change the variable types from double to int and use input.nextInt() when the problem specifies integer inputs.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code consistently uses double and nextDouble() even though the assignment clearly mentions integers; this pattern suggests a misunderstanding or disregard of the specified type.

evidence.snippet:
double v0 = input.nextDouble ( ) ; // starting velocity
double v1 = input.nextDouble ( ) ; // final velocity
double t = input.nextDouble ( ) ; // time
evidence.note: All user inputs are read as doubles via nextDouble(), not as integers, contrary to the requirement to read integers.

misconceptions.name: Not using a loop or repeated structure to handle multiple inputs
misconceptions.description: The code reads a fixed small number of values with separate statements and does not use any loop to process the required set of 5 numbers.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that reading a few values with separate statements is sufficient, without needing a loop to handle a fixed count of inputs.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To process 5 numbers in a uniform way (e.g., to compute a sum), a loop should iterate exactly 5 times, reading and processing each input within the loop body.
symptoms: Exactly three input statements are written out manually
There is no for or while loop anywhere in the program
misconceptions.root_cause: Lack of understanding or application of loops to manage repeated input operations.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Use a for-loop (or while-loop) that runs 5 times, reading each integer and updating the sum inside the loop body.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The problem requires processing 5 integers; the code reads only three values without any loop, indicating the student did not apply looping to this context.

evidence.snippet:
double v0 = input.nextDouble ( ) ; // starting velocity
double v1 = input.nextDouble ( ) ; // final velocity
double t = input.nextDouble ( ) ; // time
evidence.note: Inputs are handled by three separate calls to nextDouble() instead of a loop that could process a fixed number of values.

misconceptions.description: The student reads three floating-point numbers (`double`) using `nextDouble()` when the problem required reading five integer values (`int`) using `nextInt()`. This demonstrates a failure to correctly parse the input requirements of the assignment (quantity and type).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the required input involves 3 double values (v0, v1, t) for an unrelated physics calculation.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task requires reading 5 integers. The student should use `input.nextInt()` five times, typically inside a loop.

Variable names reflect an unrelated physics problem

evidence.snippet:

misconceptions.name: Submitting Code for an Unrelated Problem (Average Acceleration)
misconceptions.description: The student implemented logic to calculate average acceleration using the formula `(v1 - v0) / t`. This solution is entirely irrelevant to the assigned problem, which required finding the sum of even numbers among the inputs. The code lacks fundamental requirements like a loop structure, conditional checks for even numbers, and an accumulator.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have copied or submitted code intended for a different, likely physics-related, assignment.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must iterate 5 times, check if each input is even using the modulo operator (`%`), and add it to a running sum accumulator if it is even.
symptoms: Missing loop structure (Task 2)
Missing conditional logic (Task 3)
Missing accumulator (Task 4)
Executing calculations for acceleration (unrelated problem)
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to follow problem specifications (either due to misunderstanding, or submitting the wrong file).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Start over by defining the necessary variables (Scanner, sum accumulator) and implementing the required control structure (a loop running 5 times) before writing specific calculations.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: High confidence, as the printed prompt and calculation formula are unambiguous identifiers of the average acceleration problem.

evidence.note: The user prompt is for an unrelated task.

evidence.snippet: double acceleration = ( v1 - v0 ) / t ; // compute acceleration
evidence.note: Performs computation for acceleration instead of sum of evens.
Prints acceleration instead of the required sum.

misconceptions.name: Complete Task Mismatch
misconceptions.description: Student submitted code for a completely different problem (calculating average acceleration from velocity and time) instead of the assigned problem (sum of even numbers from 5 integers).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have either submitted the wrong file or misunderstood the assignment entirely, as the code solves a physics/kinematics problem rather than the sum of even numbers problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading exactly 5 integers, identifying which are even (divisible by 2), and printing their sum. The submitted code reads 3 doubles and calculates acceleration instead.

Uses double type instead of int
Performs acceleration calculation (v1 - v0) / t instead of summing even numbers
Output is 'The average acceleration is...' instead of 'Sum of even numbers: ...'
No loop structure to process 5 inputs
No modulo operation to check for even numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: Student submitted code from a different assignment or problem entirely, suggesting either file mix-up, misunderstanding of requirements, or incomplete submission process.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Carefully verify you are working on the correct problem. Read the problem statement again: sum of 5 integers, keep only even numbers (where n % 2 == 0), and output the sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Extremely high confidence. The submitted code is completely unrelated to the assigned problem. The problem explicitly asks for 5 integers and sum of even numbers, while the code reads 3 doubles and calculates acceleration.

evidence.note: Code reads 3 doubles and calculates acceleration instead of reading 5 integers and summing even numbers.
Output statement computes acceleration, not sum of even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Missing Loop Structure
misconceptions.description: No loop is present in the code. The problem requires processing 5 integers, which typically necessitates a loop structure (for or while).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student either did not recognize the need for iteration or chose to hardcode inputs without looping.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: When processing multiple inputs (5 integers), a loop structure should be used to read and process each value iteratively rather than hardcoding individual input statements.
symptoms: Only 3 input statements despite needing 5 integers
No for loop or while loop present
Code does not scale or demonstrate understanding of iteration
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding of problem requirements or incomplete implementation of the correct solution approach.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Use a for loop to iterate 5 times: for(int i = 0; i < 5; i++) { read an integer, check if even, accumulate sum }
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: No loop structure exists in the code. The submitted code handles only 3 inputs instead of 5.

evidence.note: Three separate input statements instead of a loop to read 5 integers.

misconceptions.name: Missing Conditional for Even Check
misconceptions.description: No conditional statement exists to check if a number is even using the modulo operator (n % 2 == 0).
misconceptions.student_belief: The student did not implement any logic to filter even numbers.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To identify even numbers, use the conditional: if (number % 2 == 0) to check if the remainder when divided by 2 is zero.
symptoms: No if statement checking for even numbers
No modulo (%) operator used
All calculations performed without filtering
misconceptions.root_cause: Student submitted code for an entirely different problem that does not require conditional even/odd checking.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Add a conditional inside the loop: if (number % 2 == 0) { sum += number; }
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code contains no conditional logic whatsoever. It performs only arithmetic calculations on three inputs.

evidence.note: Code performs a mathematical calculation without any conditional filtering for even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Missing Accumulator for Sum
misconceptions.description: No accumulator variable is used to sum even numbers. The code performs a single calculation instead.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student did not implement an accumulator pattern to track the running sum.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: An accumulator variable (initialized to 0) should be incremented by each even number found, then printed as the final result.
symptoms: No sum variable initialized to 0
No accumulation of values in a loop
Output displays acceleration instead of sum
misconceptions.root_cause: Wrong problem entirely; the submitted code solves a physics problem, not the sum of even numbers problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Initialize int sum = 0; then inside the loop, add: if (number % 2 == 0) sum += number; Finally print: System.out.println("Sum of even numbers: " + sum);
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code does not contain any accumulator logic. It calculates and prints a single value (acceleration) instead of accumulating a sum.

evidence.snippet:
double acceleration = ( v1 - v0 ) / t ;

System.out.println ( "The average acceleration is " + acceleration ) ;
evidence.note: Code computes a single value and prints it, rather than accumulating a sum of even numbers.

misconceptions.description: The program never checks whether a number is even (using n % 2 == 0 or similar), so it cannot distinguish even numbers from odd ones.
